newsitem.title: UK: 'Cotton Outlook' sees more active global demand.
newsitem.headline: 'Cotton Outlook' sees more active global demand.

text.p: A more active demand for cotton has been noted on many markets, the latest Cotton Outlook report said.
It added in its January 17 issue that U.S. cotton had become more prominent amongst growths traded.
Some contracts had also been arranged in Central Asian while Indian styles had continued to dominate the "coarse market". Business had also been observed in Australian and West African, it added.
New York futures were a little firmer. Some mills had been prepared to pay firm prices in order to secure quality and shipment requirements, the report said.

Despite a projected rise in U.S. exports, the United States Department of Agriculture increased its forecast of the end-of-season carryover in its January supply and demand appraisal, the report said.
Insect populations in the U.S. should be limited in advance of new crop planting by wintry weather across the U.S. cotton belt.
Insect pressures on Australia's cotton crop have also continued to be light, the report noted, but the crop development remains 10 days late after lower temperatures.

West European spinners reported generally favourable trading conditions, Cotton Outlook said. The strength of the U.S. dollar appeared to be a favourable influence on several EU textile markets, it added.
Pakistan's share of Far Eastern cotton yarn markets is under threat from Indian mills, while Chinese yarn and cloth export prices fell by 13 percent during 1996, the report said.
